The moment you depart from vanilla experience to mods, your options practically explode on what you can do.

The base game is, frankly, a masterpiece and disgrace at the same time.

The developers need to take a look at what mods are most sought after that enhance the base game and work (GASP) to incorporate that aspect into the base game, period.

Owning every M&B title ever released i am very pleased with what Taleworlds has delivered here, minus a few minor details.
Story was never M&Bs strong point, which is a good thing in my opinion. Instead the game focuses on building armies and fighting medival battles while (hopefully) expanding an ever growing dynasty kingdom on the grand strategy board.
My main points of critique are:

1. Technically the game has only become more of what it already was (not a bad thing as well), while only adding very few improved battlefield mechanics and still heavily lacking more important ones, like: Better formations (okay, we do get a minor improvement here and it seems to have taken a substantial amount of work, but...bruh), RTS Camera (can be modded in though), and/or not even a map that could be used to give tactical orders (M&B 1 actually had this).
On top of that you are not even able to assign troops to formations yourself any more, which means that we even made a loss on that end. Not a massive one, but it was useful for leveling up troops or protecting more vulnerable units.

2. Strategically very stupid AI.
Leaders will declare war and sign peace treaties at random for no apparent reason.
Declaring a war in the real world is a very serious business that will draw existential repercussions. In M&B, Leaders seemingly will declare war because they got up with the wrong leg in the morning and sign a peace treaty because a ray of sunshine tickled them just right.
They have no deeper strategic goals, no revenge to take, no damsel to rescue, no cultural difference to equalize, no barbarians to civilize, no faith to spread, and no ambition to greatness or starving population to feed and settle.
Or... well they actually DO have all these things, but they won't act on it.

And while this does of course offer plenty of moral justification for the player to become the next Ghengis Khan/Alexander/Cesar/Habsburger and brutally overthrow all those petty minds and rule in their stead, it makes the entire interaction with other lords and leaders rather pointless and bland.
Why waste time on improving relations with a noble when i will just chop their head off in a later campaign to conquer their homeland anyways?

3. No reinforcements, battles take place in a timeless void.
As is, and was with all previous titles, you can just wait until a 1000+ men strong army disbands and splits up into its constituent groups to attack nicely sized 120 men strong chunks of troops with your 300 men strong group. So long as the other groups are not within a certain very limited radius around that group they will not intervene, allowing you to slaughter most of the chunks one after the other without having to fear facing off aginst overwhelming odds.
It would have been great at this point if surrounding groups within a larger radius would (if quantities allowed) get the call to move to that battle and arrived on the scene with a delay - or at least be underway and therefore closer to the player if the battle was over before they arrived.
In battle a timer could be displayed for each group's arrival time, simulating progression of time and troop movements as the battle wages.
A system like that was used in "Freeman", and while the game was otherwise a complete failure, they at least understood that this was an essential realism enhancement for M&B-style games.

Anyways, my 1st world complaints aside: I am very happy with the depth that is theoretically possible in terms of kingdom management, NPC-Relations, Diplomacy, Strategy and Tactics... once modders start/continue fleshing all of these things out.
To that end it would be very helpful if Taleworlds didn't fubar all their efforts with every second patch though.

Reviewing this game is tricky.  Despite its shortcomings, there's still nothing on the market that's really like Bannerlord.  The hitboxing is TIGHT, the battles are huge and tactical, the map feels alive.  And the new 1.3+ patch has improved the game.  But, there are things I would've told myself:

1. The game has a lot of mechanics, but it doesn't explain all of them.  You'll need to watch guides on YouTube to play well, start on the lowest difficulty setting.  The directional blocking is simple to learn, hard to master.  For advanced battlefield tactics, the best source is TacticalEnlightenment on YouTube.  Don't declare your own kingdom unless you have >100k gold.  Don't start beheading nobles unless you don't mind having enemies.

2.  You don't need to conquer all of Calradia, that's boring.  Most people find being a mercenary more fun.  This is a sandbox game, do whatever you feel like doing.

3.  This game has timewasting RPG mechanics.  A younger me tolerated that garbage (in Warband), but older me has no tolerance for it.  You can enable "fast mode" settings to speed up leveling, and use console commands to give a bunch of focus points.  Don't feel obligated to waste your own time with a shallow game mechanic (RPG leveling).

I highly recommend this game.  We (the fans) often feel it "could've been the greatest game ever, but mistakes were made".  I also think that.  But there's still nothing else, like the Mount and Blade series.

Mount & Blade II â€” Bannerlord: A promising foundation that never truly evolves.

Iâ€™ve had a long loveâ€“hate relationship with Bannerlord. Over the years, I hoped the series would grow beyond its rough foundations, especially given its enormous potential and underrepresented niche. Unfortunately, despite better graphics and some refinements, Bannerlord feels almost identical to its predecessorsâ€”and not in a good way. The investment and iteration from game to game are barely noticeable.

Bannerlord is marketed as a fusion of RPG and grand strategy, yet it struggles to capitalize on either side of that formula. Instead, it leans heavily on the same janky RPG systems while giving only surface-level attention to the strategic layer.

Combat: Simple, Abusable, and AI-Dependent

The melee system remains basic but incredibly exploitable. Combat often encourages gimmicksâ€”horse-archer spam, kick-throwing exploits, and other cheesy tacticsâ€”because the AI and systems themselves simply canâ€™t respond intelligently.

Troops struggle with even rudimentary battlefield behavior. They rarely do anything beyond facing the enemy, and even that fails at times. The player can abuse this endlessly: form a line, let the enemy crash into it, circle behind, and clean house. Only the occasional stray soldier will peel off to bother you, and itâ€™s usually an easy 1v1.

The same issues plague formations. Under arrow fire, shield walls donâ€™t adjust, reposition, or sidestep; they just march directly forward. Unless the player micromanages every tiny movement, units expose themselves to damage because the AI canâ€™t handle nuanced positioning.

Strategic Layer: Restrictive and Unrewarding

Diplomacy and faction gameplay feel more like dice rolls than strategy. Instead of fixing weak AI, the developers added strict limitations to the player to prevent easy steamrolling. Influence costs, arbitrary restrictions, and slow progression all work to hold you back, not because itâ€™s strategically meaningful, but because the AI needs guardrails to survive.

Recent updates have made things worse by giving AI parties near-constant access to fully trained end-tier troops. Meanwhile, the player deals with attrition and a rotating cast of recruits, exposing major faction imbalances. After three years, some cultures still lack meaningful weaknesses while others have glaring ones.

Even leveling your clan to field more parties doesnâ€™t solve the issue. Companion-led parties act autonomouslyâ€”often suicidally. They wander into bad fights, get absorbed into other lordsâ€™ armies, or just sit idle. You end up grinding until you become a one-person superpower, at which point challenge evaporates.

Progression: Repetitive and Grind-Heavy

All these systems funnel the player toward one outcome: grind until you personally overpower the world. Strategy takes a back seat to RPG stat-building until you reach a point where you can brute-force everything. Bannerlord increasingly feels less like a strategic sandbox and more like an RPG grindfest with a little strategy sprinkled on top.

Final Verdict

Bannerlord is best enjoyed by players who want an RPG world where they can slowly build themselves into an unstoppable forceâ€”similar to games like Kenshi. If thatâ€™s your goal, Bannerlord delivers a satisfying power fantasy.

But those seeking meaningful grand strategy, smart AI, or evolving systems will find the experience lacking. After years of development and three years on the market, the game still relies on mods and community work to reach the depth it shouldâ€™ve had at launch.

With new competitors appearing in the genre, I can only hope TaleWorlds steps up and finally delivers the rich, strategic experience Bannerlord has always promised but never quite realized.

Bannerlord is a prime example of [b]folly[/b] and [b]hubris[/b] in gaming development, it should be studied. TaleWorlds Entertainment created Warband, a game that I'd say is groundbreaking and quite revolutionary at the very least, it went on to become very popular and spawned a huge community of modders; and then these very same developer created Bannerlord.

Bannerlord on its own by no means is a bad game; putting aside the various bugs and glitches for a minute it has good graphics, decent battle system, etc etc. People new to the Mount & Blade franchise would enjoy vanilla Bannerlord, and probably more after trying out the mods. The problem starts when Bannerlord is compared to its predecessor. Yeah, Warband is just [i]that[/i] good, it's like comparing a [b]Beef Wellington[/b] to the [b]feces[/b] it became later in the day.

My first 4 hours of playing vanilla Warband, I was smitten; there were so many things to do, an intricate system to learn about, so many things to try out. Meanwhile my first 4 hours of playing Bannerlord, I was bored. Nothing is happening on the map, even after I activated the cheat mode to teleport around the map and max scouting stat, I see nothing is happening. No lords battling bandits, no caravans battling looters, heck I barely seen any bandits or looters roaming around. I see things happening in the log though, but that's it, just some flavoured text.

How did this come to pass from the very same developers who created Warband? Not to mention the biggest elephant in the room, that is, for a game propped by modding community for years, every time there's an update it always break the mods.

But hey, I heard rumors that these people are some greedy corrupt w$nkers who updates the game once in a while simply just to get the grant from their government going--to prove to their government that they're still in the business, so I won't put much hope in the future of this game and the franchise as a whole.
